docs.lead_paragraph: A hospital study designed to test a heartburn remedy on children was partly to blame for the death of a 9-month-old boy, the Allegheny County coroner has ruled. When the boy died in November, the coroner, Cyril Wecht, said the cause was sudden infant death syndrome. But on Tuesday, Dr. Wecht amended the death certificate to say that the inclusion of the boy, Gage Stevens, in a study of the drug Propulsid had also been a factor.

headline.main: Death of Infant Is Linked To Hospital Study of a Drug

docs.abstract: Allegheny County (Pa) coroner rules that hospital study designed to test a heartburn remedy on children was partly to blame for death of 9-month-old boy; when boy died in November, coroner, Dr Cyril Wecht, said cause was sudden infant death syndrome; Wecht now says in amended death certificate that inclusion of boy, Gage Stevens, in a study of drug Propulsid had also been a factor; manufacturer of drug, Janssen Pharmaceutical Inc, announced last month that it would stop marketing drug (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 U.S. Expresses Optimism After Missile Negotiations Clinton administration officials said after a second round of meetings with the Russian foreign minister that they had detected a readiness in Moscow to explore all avenues toward resolving the standoff over the missile defense system that the United States wants to build. But they acknowledged that the Russians had not made any significant shifts. A1 Gov. George W. Bush also met with the Russian foreign minister, airing differences over the missile defense system and Chechnya but expressing hope that the two powers ''can work together to keep peace.'' A10

docs.lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court agreed in January to review Nebraska's ban on so-called ''partial-birth abortions,'' the justices made it clear that they were not interested in revisiting the court's precedents that established the constitutional right to abortion. As part of the state's case, Attorney General Don Stenberg of Nebraska had asked for a reconsideration of Roe v. Wade, and the court turned him down. But if the justices thought they were thereby assigning themselves only a limited set of issues to review, they were mistaken. The case will be argued on Tuesday, and the briefs that have poured into the court over the last three months are a reminder that nothing in the convoluted and seemingly endless legal battle over abortion is quite that simple.

headline.main: Narrow Abortion Case Before Court Leads to a Wider Debate

docs.abstract: References to Supreme Court's landmark Roe V. Wade decision surface repeatedly in briefs supporting and opposing Nebraska's ban on partial-birth abortions, even though justices made it clear in agreeing to review ban that they were not interested in revisiting court's precedents that established constitutional right to abortion; briefs cover entire spectrum of abortion debate and agree on virtually nothing (M)
